As Jays Conclude Best Season
ity LEWIS. M. SIEGEL
Sports Editor
The Blue Jay gridders put together their finest effort of the
campaign against their toughest
,_
elanonent and defeated Western
Maryland, 10-0, to take the
Mason-Dixon title and close out
their best season in a decade.
The game in itself was a maserPiece. Western Maryland took
the offensive from the opening
ininutes of play, and led by the
Darkling passing of quarterback
Charlie Walter, gained large
Chunks of yardage on the Hopkins defenders.
When the Terrors came close
!'0 the Homewood crew's goal,
however, the men in Blue formed
a stone wall to blunt the Greens
attack. Three Western Maryland
cl,rives before halftime resulted in
Evvo missed field goals (the WestMinister crew has not even
kicked an extra point, let alone a
field goal, all season) and a
_fumble recovered by ' Hopkins.
The home club's offense was not
Overly impressive during the first
thirty minutes of play.

The Johns Hopkins University
made worldwide news this week
when a member of its staff succeeded in pioneering a close
range study of the planet Venus
from a balloon.
'
Dr. John Strong, director of
the Johns Hopkins Laboratory of
Astrophysics and Physical Meteorology, reported this week that
he has found strong evidence
that there is water vapor on the
planet Venus. His conclusions
come after two balloonists, photographed and studied the planet
from an elevation of 15 miles
with telescope and instruments
designed by Dr. Strong and his
laboratory at Hopkins.
This discovery is of extreme
importance as it opens up the
possibility of the existence of
some form of life on Venus to
further study and investigation
by scientists.
Study by Ross, Moore
The high elevation balloon
study was made by Navy Cornmander Malcom D. Ross, of Arlington, Va.., and Charles B.
Moore, a Cambridge, Mass, scientist.
The two ascended in the
gondola of a polyethylene balloon
from the Strato-Bowl near Rapid
City, South Dakota, at 11:30 a.m.
last Saturday. They climbed to
a
peak altitude of 81,000 feet and
studied Venus through a specially designed 16-inch _telescope.
Clear View Of Venus
At this altitude the
balloonists
were above 98G;;, of the
earth's
atmosphere. Thus, most of the
dust particles and other contamination of the earth's atmosphere were far below and
they were able to obtain a much
les.s obscured view of Venus
than
is possible from the ground.
Their findings were released
upon Dr. Strong's return
to

Baltimore. He had accompanied
the group out to South Dakota
for the launching and landing
operations.
Water On Venus
At a news conference, Strong
stated that a spectograph gave
the first evidence of the presence
of water vapor on Venus.
"How much there is will take
us some time to determine because we have to analyze the results," said Strong.
Water Doubtful Before
Dr. Strong added that heretofore scientists disagreed as ,to
whether or not there was water
vapor in the atmosphere of
Venus. "It was not determinable
before because we had to look
through too much water vapor
on the earth," Strong said.
"The fact that there is water
vapor on Venus is of interest;
We can't go much beyond that."
Life On Venus?
In reply to a question. Strong
pointed out that these results
neither confirm nor rule out the
possibility of life on that planet.
According to balloonist Malcom Ross the telescope and other
devices aboard the balloon repre-

sented the most elaborate set of
in.struments ever taken so high
above the surface of the earth.
Precise System
Said Ross, "For the first time
we have had a very precise system above the atmosphere—spectograph, star tracker and the

like—and this was the greatest
achievement of this flight."
Scientists stated beforehand
that the two observers would be
fortunate if they could keep the
telescope in focus for 10 minutes.
It is reported that they were able
to keep the telescope "locked on"
to the planet for about 55 minutes.

DR. JOHN STRONG
Success at long last

Strong Winds
Strong winds forced the balloon to land 350 miles from the
launching point, near Blaine,
Kansas. It was originally intended to touch down near
Chicago. The landing was made
at 4:30 on Sunday after 28'
hours aloft.
As the gondola touched down,
strong winds dragged it for more
than a half mile before the chute
caught on a barbed wire fence.
Commander Ross was shaken up
but not seriously injured..
"Tremendous Triumph"
A chief scientist for the joint
project with the United States
Navy, Dr. Strong has spent five
years designing and perfecting
some of the equipment used. A
Hopkins spokesman said this
week that the project was a
"tremendous triumph" for Dr.
Strong.

Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Dean of
Students, has released the names
of the Johns Hopkins students selected for Who's Who in American Colleges and Universities, an
annual
publication
honoring
prominent college students.

chairman; Oscar Garcia-Rivera,

C. Kerchner, president of the
Booster Club; Arie L. Kopelman, editor of the Hullabaloo.
Also chosen were: Thomas W

Registrar's Office
Issues Students
1141 Informal Slips
A total of 1,141 informal slips
warning students of prospective
D's or F's was issued during the
last few weeks, announced Registrar Irene Davis.
This figure represents more
than 10e; of the total number
of over 9,000 course cards on
record in the Registrar's office.
Miss Davis pointed out that this
figure does not mean that 1,141
students received informals, since
many undergraduates got informals in more than one course.

NEW PRODUCTS LEAD TO BETTER JOBS AT DU PONT

Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president.of the University, has been
named chairman of the Middle
Atlantic Committee selecting the
1959 Rhodes scholars.
The group will meet December
19 in Philadelphia to review the
two nominations from each of
the six areas in its jurisdiction.
They are New York, New Jersey,
Pennsylvania, Delaware, West
Virginia, and - Maryland-Washington.
The Maryland-Washington selection ,committee will meet December 16 to recommend its two
candidates to the Middle Atlantic
group.
From the twelve candidates
from this area, the district committee will select four Rhodes
scholars who will go to Oxford
University in October, 1960. They

The suits these girls are wearing are
made of nylon, the first truly synthetic
fiber. It is a product of Du Pont research. Pure research. Applied research.
And research in manufacture, research
in product improvement. All require
many types of skills.
You may not discover a new fiber, but
as a technical man you can profit well
anyway. For once a product—any product—is discovered, hundreds of technical
men go to work. Pilot plants are designed. Operating procedures are devised.
New plants are built. Manufacturing
methods are improved. Product quality
is worked on,backed by Du Pont's policy:
Let's make it better...still better ...
even better. Discovery is but the starting shot; these later activities are the
game. The players? Men of every technical specialty.
You'll find a teamwork atmosphere at

DuPont. Others have. Maybe that's
part of the reason half of Du Pont's
profits today come from products unheard of twenty-five years ago.
If you join Du Pont, the men who have
worked on new products and ways to
make them are the men who will teach
you. You will be given an actual project
assignment almost at once, and you will
begin to learn your job by doing it. Advancement will come as rapidly as your
abilities permit and opportunities develop. For Du Pont personnel policy is
based firmly on the belief in promotion
from within the company strictly on a
merit basis.
For more information about career
opportunities at Du Pont, ask your placement officer for literature. Or write us.

Fraternities Discuss Special Awards Presented Goucher, Hopkins
Hazing Of Pledges To 8 Cadet Corps Seniors Glee Clubs Plan
"You cannot legislate good
Public relations. It comes from
the spirit of the fraternities."
This statement, made by a national fraternity executive, highlighted what Hopkins IFB delegate Alan Powdermaker termed
"a terrifically worthwhile" National Interfraternity Conference
last weekend in New York City.
During the course of the Golden
Convention
Anniversary
Which featured fraternity presidents, national executives and
dollege deans from all over the
United States, several matters of
business made- national news.
Item: An affirmation of the
Importance of fraternity scholarship, "in which fraternities are
failing."
Item: A resolution recommending the abolition of all fraternity
hazing because it is "rambunctious and old."
The latter item is important

for the fact that it concerns the
perennial stigma attached to
fraternity pledge activities.
The resolution, passed unanimously by the conference, in
effect "condemn(ed) all forms
of hazing that tend to degrade,
bring personal injury to, humiliate, detract from studies and
hinder the purposes for which
we are at college," according to
a report issued this morning by
Powdermaker.
"The fraternity system will
stand or fall because of academic
Powdermaker
considerations,"
quoted a college dean as saying.
"The benefits of such a conference are invaluable .. . we
could revamp the whole fraternity system here on points made
during it," Powdermaker stated
in recommending that the IFB
president and Dean of Students
be financially sponsored to attend these annual conferences in
the future.

CAREE OPPORTUNMES
IN CHEMICAL INDUSTRY!
Approaching its 50th year or specialization in industrial chemicals and
commercial explosives, ATLAS is constantly on the alert for graduate engineers seeking unusual growth opportunities. Here at ATLAS in Wilmington,
as well as in our nine manufacturing facilities and four research centers
throughout the United States, we are planning and looking, as always,
to the future.
Since YOUR future, as well as OUR OWN,could be closNy linked together
in the expansive period ahead, we invite your consideration of our oppor-

tunities.
For those who have degrees in Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, we
have a wide range of openings. Our present need is for qualified men at
every level for work in Research, Development, Sales, Management, Staff
Functions and Production. We also need imaginative graduates who seek
unusual experiences in Civil, Mechanical and Mining engineering.
Our financial rewards are many. Salaries are competitive with the industry;
our benefits are unsurpassed. And, opportunity for rapid advancement
depends on you ... our planned program of management development
will prepare you for the responsibilities you are capable of assuming.
_

ON-ITHE-JOB-TRAINING
Most new technical employees start at ATLAS with 0

a formal training course at one of the company's laboratories. Afterward, they train on
the job at an ATLAS laboratory, plant, or
scales office, where they gradually
assume increasing responsibility under
the guidance of an experienced
ATLAS staff member. Men with
specialized qualifications may
immediately begin the onthe-job phase of the training

program.

A surprisingly adept production marked the inncvation of
what I hope will become a regular • event in the Barnstormers'
repertoire as the theatrical group
presented a reading of JeanPaul Sartre's invective, "No
Exit," on Sunday, November 22.

The axiom that actors are
primarily in the hands of their
play's author was apparent in
the presentation. Sartre's play,
concerning three persons shut
together in a chamber of hell,
is above all a powerful, at times
despairingly frank, play. As the
characters slowly but deftly pick
at each • other's souls, Sartre's
meaning is vividly and frighteningly depicted. Gradually the
fear of a bath of fire and the
entrance of a Tormenter gives
way to the characters' realization
that each of the three of them is
to be eternal torcherer of the
other two.
The irony comes when their
chamber door opens and no one
of them wants to leave; they are
hopelessly, inextricably enmeshed
in each other's eternal damnation and punishment, like three
mirrors that reflect among them
the petty evils and gross sins
that have caused their fate and

The Disorganization Man
Considering the success of his venture, Diogenes could
have been searching for a leader at Johns Hopkins.
The lack of leadership is one of the basic ills of our
undergraduate life. The constant criticism heard is "it's
all because of the apathy around here" and "undergraduates are the forgotten cause at Hopkins." These arguments may settle local bull sessions and liven marijuana
parties, but they fall far short of adding anything to a
possible solution of what is, indeed, as it is called, "the
main trouble with this !w!ce& place."

now seal it. Almost triumphantly
one of them cries: "Hell is
people!"
Characters Frighteningly Real
Sandy Klewicki as Estelle
stood out by making a frighteningly real person of the character
she portrayed—the high-strung
nymphomaniac who envisions
vice as virtue and whose tragedy
lies in the fact that she can tell
the truth to no one, least of all
herself.
Robert Sessions as Garcin, the
whose
presence
hero-coward
forms at once the catalyst and
turmoil in his hell-chamber as it
did in his earth-chamber, was
high-strung and
consistently
moody in his reading.
Anne-Claude Piquet as Inez,
the lesbian who is at once dominating, demanding and pitiful,
gave a performance that was
disturbingly inconstant and perhaps a little too tense at first
but which greatly improved as
the play progressed, primarily
for the fact that her tone evolved
from an over-emotional pitch to
the shaken but steady, firm reading the part required.
Howard Rosell as the valet was
as formal and impersonal as his
part of a hell-custodian would
allow.
The almost professional touch

which rendered the production a
success was the skillful blend of
reading pace, lighting and staging, and for these elements director Arturo Echavarria and lighting manager Webster Ford are
to be commended. Mr. Echavarria's interpretation of what was
already a good play and a good
translation from the French
which might nevertheless have
bungled in
been
hopelessly
presentation was perceptive and.
competent.
Unity
With the skillful use of a
simple, morgue-like set and Mr.
Ford's adroit handling of colored
lights to heighten the play's
overall sense impressions, the
Barnstormers showed a theatrical
understanding and competence
which is too easily, and perhaps
too frequently, missing in their
major productions.
The production as a whole left
little to be desired, and I would
venture to say that "No Exit"
itself, since its impact relies upon
the handling of language and
dialogue, is perhaps best rendered as a reading. And I assure
Barnstormer president Ed Ross
that his "experiment" was a
success which might well bear
repetition with other readings
throughout the school year.

'But Al Said Something About A Formal'

As a review of any past issue of the News-Letter will
show, a staggering quantity of the mistakes, oversights
and inefficiencies in planning and carrying out student
activities can be traced directly to this lack of leadership.
Item: The Cotillion Board, an organization set up
to aid other organizations in scheduling and arranging
social affairs, is obviously failing to carry out its purposes, as witnessed by the bad management of recent
dances and the fact that sponsoring organizations have
complained of the lack of assistance from this group.
Item: The Board of Intramural Athletics. Unless
this group establishes better communications with intramural and fraternity teams and demands the respect
of its rules and regulations through stricter enforcement,
the intramural system at Hopkins will remain the shabby
and inefficient program it has been for eons.
Item: The IFB. Among the sorriest and most demanding problems is the lack of inter-fraternity communication and rapport. The inclusion of a round of
open-house parties during the spring weekend as well as
a University-recognized Greek Week program of joint
activities might be a start but would have to be proposed,
as would a much-needed Presidents' IFB, by the fraternity representatives themselves.

Engineering of microwave relay and carrier systems keeps Bryan Clinton's job
interesting and challenging,

"I got the engineering career I wanted
and right in my own home state"
In 1955, William Bryan Clinton, Jr., got
his B.S. in Mechanical Engineering at
Clemson College. Now Bryan's with
Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph
Company at Columbia, South Carolina.
He's doing specific planning of long distance communications projects involving cable carrier facilities and microwave
radio relay systems.
Bryan chose a career w ith Southern
Bell over several other offers. :There
were three things that were most important to me," he says. "First, I wanted to
go with an established, growing company
where I could grow,too. Second,I wanted
thorough basic training to get started off
right, plus participation in development
programs to keep me moving ahead. And,
third, I wanted to stay in the South."

After 15 months of on-the-job training
in various phases of company operations,
Bryan was assigned to the Engineering
Department at Columbia, S. C. His work
with carrier systems and microwave
radio projects has involved him directly
in the growth of the company. And he's
broadened his experience through development courses in management, general
engineering, engineering economy, and
microwave relay systems.

But the Hopkins defense must
not be slighted. The Jay "stone
wall" held the opposition to under 95 yards rushing per game
and only 140 overall yardage
each contest. Four of the eight
opponents were shut out, •while
only Hampden-Sydney was able
to score more than one touchdown on the men in Blue. As a
matter of fact, it was this club,
in giving the Jays their only defeat of the campaign, that rolled
up more than half (33 of the 51)
of the points scored against Hopkins all season.
The defensive "radar crew" deserves special mention since it
allowed the opponents to complete only 24 per-cent of their
passes for less than 50 yards a
game; this unit intercepted 24 of
its foes 109 passes, while the
latter could complete only 26.
Club jelled after Defeat
It took a loosing game with
Hampden-Sydney after three
straight "easy" victories to make
this Hopkins club jell and show
how good a club it really could
be. The "must" 13-6 victory over
Randolph-Macon and the 28-0
shellacking of a strong Swarthmore eleven that followed proved
that the Jays could win with the
pressure on them.
The desire of the defensive
unit evidenced itself in the
fourth quarter against Dickinson.
With the Homewood squad leading 40-0 and second and thirdstringers in for the Jays, Dickinson was moving toward the Hopkins goal. The tension could be
seen mounting on the Blue Jay
bench, as the first unit players

begged to go in, to keep the
opponents from scoring.
They went in, and did just
that—taking over on their own
ten. As the successful defenders
walked toward the bench, some
could be seen gritting their teeth
---"we just couldn't let 'em get
that TD." The score was 40-0,
and the Hopkins club was just
as determined as if the margin
was only six points. It is of this
stuff that champions are made.

News-Letter 3rd;
Receives Mention
In PiDE Contest
The 1958-59 News-Letter has
won recognition in national collegiate newspaper competition.
The recognition came in the
form of sole Honorable Mention
position among colleges and universities with undergraduate enrollment between 1,200 and 2,500
in a nationwide contest sponsored by Pi Delta Epsilon, national honorary journalism society.
The award. which amounts to
a third-place recognition since
it follows first and second place
citations, was announced at the
50th anniversary convention of
Pi Delta Epsilon on November
13-15 at Lehigh University in
Pennsylvania.
Entries were submitted to the
annual contest by college and
university publications all over
America and were judged according to writing and layout
style, editorial technique and
overall journalistic excellence.
The 1958-59 News-Letter was
under the editorship of M. Albert Figinski and H. Rutherford
Turnbull III, both in the class
of 1959.

Channels will be composed of an
editorial board and business
staff to be selected by interview.

for the editorial board and business staff now and hope to complete interviews. before Christmas," Sundermeyer. Six positions are open, two-thirds of

"will be changed to a smaller

to finance the publication, which

The annual Gilman Step-Sing
and "Y" Christmas Party will
be held beginning at 8 p.m. on
Wednesday, December 16.
The traditional merry-making will be initiated with a program of Christmas carols sung

holiday season.
Immediately following these
festivities a gala Christmas'
Party will be held in Levering
Hall "to which all Hopkins personnel, their dates and friends

Towson State Teachers, the JHU
banjo club and the boys glee
club quartet), and dancing.

The Johns Hopkins University
made worldwide news this week
when a member of its staff succeeded in pioneering a close
range study of the planet Venus
from a balloon.
'
Dr. John Strong, director of
the Johns Hopkins Laboratory of
Astrophysics and Physical Meteorology, reported this week that
he has found strong evidence
that there is water vapor on the
planet Venus. His conclusions
come after two balloonists, photographed and studied the planet
from an elevation of 15 miles
with telescope and instruments
designed by Dr. Strong and his
laboratory at Hopkins.
This discovery is of extreme
importance as it opens up the
possibility of the existence of
some form of life on Venus to
further study and investigation
by scientists.
Study by Ross, Moore
The high elevation balloon
study was made by Navy Cornmander Malcom D. Ross, of Arlington, Va.., and Charles B.
Moore, a Cambridge, Mass, scientist.
The two ascended in the
gondola of a polyethylene balloon
from the Strato-Bowl near Rapid
City, South Dakota, at 11:30 a.m.
last Saturday. They climbed to
a
peak altitude of 81,000 feet and
studied Venus through a specially designed 16-inch _telescope.
Clear View Of Venus
At this altitude the
balloonists
were above 98G;;, of the
earth's
atmosphere. Thus, most of the
dust particles and other contamination of the earth's atmosphere were far below and
they were able to obtain a much
les.s obscured view of Venus
than
is possible from the ground.
Their findings were released
upon Dr. Strong's return
to

Water On Venus
At a news conference, Strong
stated that a spectograph gave
the first evidence of the presence
of water vapor on Venus.
"How much there is will take
us some time to determine because we have to analyze the results," said Strong.
Water Doubtful Before
Dr. Strong added that heretofore scientists disagreed as ,to
whether or not there was water
vapor in the atmosphere of
Venus. "It was not determinable
before because we had to look
through too much water vapor
on the earth," Strong said.
"The fact that there is water
vapor on Venus is of interest;
We can't go much beyond that."
Life On Venus?
In reply to a question. Strong
pointed out that these results
neither confirm nor rule out the
possibility of life on that planet.
According to balloonist Malcom Ross the telescope and other
devices aboard the balloon repre-

sented the most elaborate set of
in.struments ever taken so high
above the surface of the earth.
Precise System
Said Ross, "For the first time
we have had a very precise system above the atmosphere—spectograph, star tracker and the

like—and this was the greatest
achievement of this flight."
Scientists stated beforehand
that the two observers would be
fortunate if they could keep the
telescope in focus for 10 minutes.
It is reported that they were able
to keep the telescope "locked on"
to the planet for about 55 minutes.

Strong Winds
Strong winds forced the balloon to land 350 miles from the
launching point, near Blaine,
Kansas. It was originally intended to touch down near
Chicago. The landing was made
at 4:30 on Sunday after 28'
hours aloft.
As the gondola touched down,
strong winds dragged it for more
than a half mile before the chute
caught on a barbed wire fence.
Commander Ross was shaken up
but not seriously injured..
"Tremendous Triumph"
A chief scientist for the joint
project with the United States
Navy, Dr. Strong has spent five
years designing and perfecting
some of the equipment used. A
Hopkins spokesman said this
week that the project was a
"tremendous triumph" for Dr.
Strong.

"You cannot legislate good
Public relations. It comes from
the spirit of the fraternities."
This statement, made by a national fraternity executive, highlighted what Hopkins IFB delegate Alan Powdermaker termed
"a terrifically worthwhile" National Interfraternity Conference
last weekend in New York City.
During the course of the Golden
Convention
Anniversary
Which featured fraternity presidents, national executives and
dollege deans from all over the
United States, several matters of
business made- national news.
Item: An affirmation of the
Importance of fraternity scholarship, "in which fraternities are
failing."
Item: A resolution recommending the abolition of all fraternity
hazing because it is "rambunctious and old."
The latter item is important

for the fact that it concerns the
perennial stigma attached to
fraternity pledge activities.
The resolution, passed unanimously by the conference, in
effect "condemn(ed) all forms
of hazing that tend to degrade,
bring personal injury to, humiliate, detract from studies and
hinder the purposes for which
we are at college," according to
a report issued this morning by
Powdermaker.
"The fraternity system will
stand or fall because of academic
Powdermaker
considerations,"
quoted a college dean as saying.
"The benefits of such a conference are invaluable .. . we
could revamp the whole fraternity system here on points made
during it," Powdermaker stated
in recommending that the IFB
president and Dean of Students
be financially sponsored to attend these annual conferences in
the future.

A surprisingly adept production marked the inncvation of
what I hope will become a regular • event in the Barnstormers'
repertoire as the theatrical group
presented a reading of JeanPaul Sartre's invective, "No
Exit," on Sunday, November 22.

The axiom that actors are
primarily in the hands of their
play's author was apparent in
the presentation. Sartre's play,
concerning three persons shut
together in a chamber of hell,
is above all a powerful, at times
despairingly frank, play. As the
characters slowly but deftly pick
at each • other's souls, Sartre's
meaning is vividly and frighteningly depicted. Gradually the
fear of a bath of fire and the
entrance of a Tormenter gives
way to the characters' realization
that each of the three of them is
to be eternal torcherer of the
other two.
The irony comes when their
chamber door opens and no one
of them wants to leave; they are
hopelessly, inextricably enmeshed
in each other's eternal damnation and punishment, like three
mirrors that reflect among them
the petty evils and gross sins
that have caused their fate and

The Disorganization Man
Considering the success of his venture, Diogenes could
have been searching for a leader at Johns Hopkins.
The lack of leadership is one of the basic ills of our
undergraduate life. The constant criticism heard is "it's
all because of the apathy around here" and "undergraduates are the forgotten cause at Hopkins." These arguments may settle local bull sessions and liven marijuana
parties, but they fall far short of adding anything to a
possible solution of what is, indeed, as it is called, "the
main trouble with this !w!ce& place."

stood out by making a frighteningly real person of the character
she portrayed—the high-strung
nymphomaniac who envisions
vice as virtue and whose tragedy
lies in the fact that she can tell
the truth to no one, least of all
herself.

the play progressed, primarily

With the skillful use of a
simple, morgue-like set and Mr.
Ford's adroit handling of colored
lights to heighten the play's
overall sense impressions, the
Barnstormers showed a theatrical

The production as a whole left

'But Al Said Something About A Formal'

As a review of any past issue of the News-Letter will
show, a staggering quantity of the mistakes, oversights
and inefficiencies in planning and carrying out student
activities can be traced directly to this lack of leadership.
Item: The Cotillion Board, an organization set up
to aid other organizations in scheduling and arranging
social affairs, is obviously failing to carry out its purposes, as witnessed by the bad management of recent
dances and the fact that sponsoring organizations have
complained of the lack of assistance from this group.
Item: The Board of Intramural Athletics. Unless
this group establishes better communications with intramural and fraternity teams and demands the respect
of its rules and regulations through stricter enforcement,
the intramural system at Hopkins will remain the shabby
and inefficient program it has been for eons.
Item: The IFB. Among the sorriest and most demanding problems is the lack of inter-fraternity communication and rapport. The inclusion of a round of
open-house parties during the spring weekend as well as
a University-recognized Greek Week program of joint
activities might be a start but would have to be proposed,
as would a much-needed Presidents' IFB, by the fraternity representatives themselves.

Engineering of microwave relay and carrier systems keeps Bryan Clinton's job
interesting and challenging,

"I got the engineering career I wanted
and right in my own home state"
In 1955, William Bryan Clinton, Jr., got
his B.S. in Mechanical Engineering at
Clemson College. Now Bryan's with
Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph
Company at Columbia, South Carolina.
He's doing specific planning of long distance communications projects involving cable carrier facilities and microwave
radio relay systems.
Bryan chose a career w ith Southern
Bell over several other offers. :There
were three things that were most important to me," he says. "First, I wanted to
go with an established, growing company
where I could grow,too. Second,I wanted
thorough basic training to get started off
right, plus participation in development
programs to keep me moving ahead. And,
third, I wanted to stay in the South."

After 15 months of on-the-job training
in various phases of company operations,
Bryan was assigned to the Engineering
Department at Columbia, S. C. His work
with carrier systems and microwave
radio projects has involved him directly
in the growth of the company. And he's
broadened his experience through development courses in management, general
engineering, engineering economy, and
microwave relay systems.
"I know I'm with a fast-growing company and I feel I'm really participating
in its growth," Bryan says."What's more,
I'm getting the training I need to keep
me abreast of new communications developments and take better advantage of
advancement opportunities when they
come along."

Bran Clinton earned a B.S. degree in Mechanical Engineering: He's one of many young college men pursuing
rewarding careers with the Bell Telephone Companies.
Find out about opportunities for you. Talk with the Bell
interviewer when he visits your campus—and read the
Bell Telephone booklet on file in your Placement Office.

But the Hopkins defense must

and only 140 overall yardage

The defensive "radar crew" deserves special mention since it
allowed the opponents to complete only 24 per-cent of their

latter could complete only 26.
Club jelled after Defeat
It took a loosing game with
Hampden-Sydney after three
straight "easy" victories to make
this Hopkins club jell and show
how good a club it really could
be. The "must" 13-6 victory over
Randolph-Macon and the 28-0
shellacking of a strong Swarthmore eleven that followed proved
that the Jays could win with the
pressure on them.
The desire of the defensive
unit evidenced itself in the
fourth quarter against Dickinson.
With the Homewood squad leading 40-0 and second and thirdstringers in for the Jays, Dickinson was moving toward the Hopkins goal. The tension could be
seen mounting on the Blue Jay
bench, as the first unit players

begged to go in, to keep the
opponents from scoring.
They went in, and did just
that—taking over on their own
ten. As the successful defenders
walked toward the bench, some
could be seen gritting their teeth
---"we just couldn't let 'em get
that TD." The score was 40-0,
and the Hopkins club was just
as determined as if the margin
was only six points. It is of this
stuff that champions are made.

News-Letter 3rd;
Receives Mention
In PiDE Contest
The 1958-59 News-Letter has
won recognition in national collegiate newspaper competition.
The recognition came in the
form of sole Honorable Mention
position among colleges and universities with undergraduate enrollment between 1,200 and 2,500
in a nationwide contest sponsored by Pi Delta Epsilon, national honorary journalism society.
The award. which amounts to
a third-place recognition since
it follows first and second place
citations, was announced at the
50th anniversary convention of
Pi Delta Epsilon on November
13-15 at Lehigh University in
Pennsylvania.
Entries were submitted to the
annual contest by college and
university publications all over
America and were judged according to writing and layout
style, editorial technique and
overall journalistic excellence.
The 1958-59 News-Letter was
under the editorship of M. Albert Figinski and H. Rutherford
Turnbull III, both in the class
of 1959.

Channels will be composed of an
editorial board and business
staff to be selected by interview.
"We are receiving applications
for the editorial board and business staff now and hope to complete interviews. before Christmas," Sundermeyer. Six positions are open, two-thirds of
them on the editorial board.
"This (editorial) board will review and select the contents for
each issue and will form editorial policy," Sundermeyer noted.
"We have received many contributions for our next issue and
have begun to select those which
will be published," Sundermeyer
explained.
Channels will appear in February and May, and its format
"will be changed to a smaller
page-size but greater number of
pages," he continued.
Advertising is now being enlisted from local establishments
to finance the publication, which
will cost between $300 and $400.
"We expect to function more
efficiently when the whole staff
is set up, and I am confident
that we can produce a good issue
representative of student- creawriting,"

situation persists, there will be
some drastic changes next year."

The annual Gilman Step-Sing
and "Y" Christmas Party will
be held beginning at 8 p.m. on
Wednesday, December 16.
The traditional merry-making will be initiated with a program of Christmas carols sung
by the Johns Hopkins Glee Club
on the steps of Gilman Hall,
which will be brightly illuminated for the occasion. At the
same time the fir tree beside
Homewood House will glow when
its decorations are lit for the
holiday season.
Immediately following these
festivities a gala Christmas'
Party will be held in Levering
Hall "to which all Hopkins personnel, their dates and friends
are invited free," according to
chairman Bill Westerkam.
The party, co-sponsored this
year by the Hopkins "Y" and
cafeteria, will feature refreshments (hot chocolate, cookies, et
al), entertainment (a trio from
Towson State Teachers, the JHU
banjo club and the boys glee
club quartet), and dancing.
Contests, such as the perennial pie-eating one, will be included.
